awd_titl_txt: Planning Grant: Engineering Research Center for Next Generations of Wireless  Telecommunication (WiTeC)
awd_abstract_narration:
The Planning Grants for Engineering Research Centers competition was run as a pilot solicitation within the ERC program. Planning grants are not required as part of the full ERC competition, but intended to build capacity among teams to plan for convergent, center-scale engineering research.

The Covid-19 pandemic reinforced the need and importance of telecommunications more than any other event in the history of mankind. It, single-handedly, kept businesses, governments, academia and societies running in spite of the mandated social isolations and quarantines. The need for the human race to survive in the face of adversities and natural calamities continues to evolve where a world of ubiquitous connectivity becomes a necessity. From precision agriculture to artificial intelligence driven precision medicine, from holographic teleportation to space connectivity, it is important to create a world which pushes the boundaries of our current telecommunication technologies so that we can survive the next pandemic and/or calamity better and stronger. 1.5 billion children required online education during the COVID-19 pandemic and 51% of Americans worked from home in 2020. However, 44 million households in America and about 40% each of African Americans, Hispanics and Native Americans residing on tribal lands do not have access to broadband services owing to the lack of access and affordability. It is not surprising that the pandemic has taken its most severe toll on the socio-economic and mental well-being of these ethnic classes. Without access to online healthcare and government mandates and notifications about the spread of the virus, the Navajo Nation had the highest per capita infection rate in the country and the highest job-losses occurred in the African American community.  Exposure, affordability and literacy in technology can bridge the gap. The goal of this planning grant is to understand the needs of these communities and thereby design impactful telecommunications systems to help level the playing field. 

The WiTeC ERC aims to amalgamate a convergent research team from across the nation to successfully create the next generation of telecommunication with omnipresent connectivity and unprecedented reliability and latency -leaps beyond what current telecommunication systems can offer. It will be a hub for breakthrough technological research challenges like Tbps-level of data rates and microsecond orders of delay that even current millimeter wave technology cannot achieve. It will serve as a platform for discourse on futuristic and widely variant use cases, ranging from precision agriculture to CubeSat (cubic millimeter sized satellites) communication that can provide connectivity even in the remotest part of rural America. The intellectual merit of WiTec will lie in the fundamental research challenges it will undertake, namely (i) exploring radio technologies for ubiquitous connectivity with unprecedented speed, reliability and latency, (ii) innovating greener and power efficient future telecommunication systems and (iii) novel ways of utilizing pervasive artificial intelligence to build a telecommunication system that is smarter and more robust than ever before. The Center will also be the seat for developing groundbreaking telecommunications research test-beds in novel radio technologies.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
In 2021, researchers at San Diego State University’s Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering were awarded a $100K planning grant to create a multidisciplinary team and pursue the establishment of an NSF-funded Engineering Research Center (ERC) with its headquarters at SDSU. The goal of the envisioned Center, named ConnectU, would be to connect the 44 million Americans who are still without broadband connectivity and facilitate diverse services from remote healthcare and education to environment monitoring. The envisioned Center aimed to solve this problem by bringing compelling new technical ideas and approaches through a cross-disciplinary engineered system built through cross-sector partnerships. This effort will be led by a unique team that not only brings convergent technology research expertise together but also a history of extensive outreach to specific populations of unconnected or under-connected American communities. The Center would also advance science education and digital literacy in the newly connected areas.

 

The team pursued this project on three fronts: (i) formation of a core partner team to manage the Center’s activities, (ii) identification of major technical research and social science objectives and (iii) discussions with the industry and targeted end-users.

 

The team formation effort was influenced by two factors- gaps in research expertise and universities in suitable locations to be the testbeds for the Center. The planning team wanted to work with 3-4 diverse unconnected communities in the country and these communities would be the testbeds where the developed technologies would be deployed and benefits made available to people in the form of wireless services for healthcare, education, etc. After many meetings, the core partner team was formed with researchers and community experts in Southern California, Florida, Alabama and Alaska. Each of these regions has large areas with relatively little connectivity, from the deserts east of San Diego to the rural areas of Florida and Alabama and the vast arctic region of northwest Alaska. These areas collectively are home to a very diverse population. As such, they would be ideal testbed locations for new wireless infrastructure that connects hitherto unconnected or under connected populations to advanced wireless services. These core partners are not only institutions with a long-standing history of successfully working with the underserved people of their region but also institutions with stellar academic programs and convergent research expertise.

 

Realizing the ConnectU vision requires major advances in many areas of engineering and social science. As part of the planning project, we identified the key technical areas where the Center should focus to enable the ConnectU vision. Based on extensive meetings with technical collaborators and the industry, the project team concluded that aerial platforms are best placed to serve the needs of rural and remote areas. Drone based platforms can connect communication satellites to users and the mobility of the platform readily allows the reconfiguration of network topology. These platforms can serve wireless users during the peak traffic hours and can be repurposed towards agricultural or environmental monitoring during off peak hours. This new paradigm requires convergent research on novel drone platforms, new communications and networking technologies, cybersecurity, and key applications such as immersive media, which will allow students to remotely attend schools and doctors to remotely evaluate patients. Furthermore, the Center’s goals will necessitate social science research as well. Sensitive and ethical introduction of new technology, revenue generation streams and digital literacy in geographically convergent communities, while being mindful of their culture, will constitute an important aspect of bringing this technology to the people who need it the most.

 

The ERC team also included people with a history of working with unconnected and underserved communities of their regions. These researchers had access to their local communities and helped us understand their needs and the nontechnical barriers. These discussions led the team to understand the social aspects of the problem and how to address them in the ERC. Alongside, the team also held meetings with representatives of private broadband consortiums and industry players like Qualcomm, Viasat and CableLabs who are working with the Government to bridge the digital divide. Through these meetings, the team got to learn the economic barriers to solving this problem in a durable manner. The time is right for an ERC to cater to this important vision.

 

To summarize, the team utilized their 2021 planning grant to identify the key technical and nontechnical barriers towards digitally integrating people in remote communities. The anecdotes they heard from people who have worked with these communities were eye opening. They leveraged the knowledge gained through this planning grant to submit an ERC pre-proposal to the NSF in October 2022.
